item.title: Pain Science in Practice (Part 8): Nociceptive, Neuropathic and Nociplastic Pain
item.description: Feld: Clinical Medicine Kategorie: Orthopedics Score: 24 Autoren: Morten Hoegh, Paul Hodges Journal: Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy Veröffentlicht: 2025-07-29 Abstract: Identification of pain descriptors provide a plausible method to consider personalisation of management of pain based on presumed underlying mechanisms. The aim is to use mechanistic pain descriptors (nociceptive, neuropathic and nociplastic pain) to guide clinical practice into an era of personalised medicine for people with pain. Clinicians should understand the concept of descriptors to improve their understanding of a mechanism-based management of chronic pain. Nonetheless, all treatment of individuals suffering from chronic pain should be holistic (i.e., person-centred). Nociplastic pain already serves as an evidence-based explanation that can help make sense of pain without any known pathology, but is not ready to be considered as a target for treatment in itself, based on the current level of evidence. To summarise, treatment outcomes may benefit when treatments are matched to patients according to mechanistic descriptors, and current research initiatives are working on bring this closer to the clinic. DOI: 10.2519/jospt.2025.13335 ISSN: 0190-6011 Tag der Erhebung (OOIR): 2025-08-25

item.title: Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome Needs a New Name—Make No Bones About It
item.description: Feld: Clinical Medicine Kategorie: Orthopedics Score: 17 Autoren: Laura M. Anderson, Stuart J. Warden, Richard W. Willy, Daniel R. Bonanno, Hylton B. Menz Journal: Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy Veröffentlicht: 2025-08-18 Abstract: Pain near the posteromedial tibia is common in running and jumping athletes. This problem has had many names, with “shin splints” and “medial tibial stress syndrome” (MTSS) the most common. The term shin splints is nonspecific and nondescript, and has never gained clinical traction. Similarly, the clinical use of MTSS with athletes and coaches is often met with confusion as ‘tibial stress’ is frequently misinterpreted as indicating a bone stress injury. With no conclusive evidence regarding the pathophysiology of MTSS, we advocate renaming it “Load Induced Medial-Leg Pain” (LIMP). LIMP avoids the use of ‘tibial stress’ which is problematic due to the unknown pathology of the condition and its confusion with bone stress injury. Using the term LIMP instead of MTSS gives clinicians, researchers, and athletes a clearer, more accurate way to approach managing exercise-related lower leg pain. DOI: 10.2519/jospt.2025.13411 ISSN: 0190-6011 Tag der Erhebung (OOIR): 2025-08-25
